posts.title: Hyper Island Toolbox
posts.intro: Contains facilitation guidelines for ideation, team building and self assesment.
posts.content: Hyper Island enables companies and individuals to develop, grow and rise to the challenges of tomorrow's transformative technology.

posts.title: Slow Down - Getting More out of Harvard by Doing Less
posts.intro: by Harry R Lewis (Dean of Harvard College). Recognize who you are, and do not rush things. Do not take anyone's advice.
posts.content:
Presidents, deans, and professors rarely tell students simple truths, for example that the strategizing and diligence that got them into the college of their choice may not, if followed thoughtlessly, lead to an adult life they will find worth living.

-Harry R. Lewis

posts.title: Bullet Journaling
posts.intro: A journaling system which only requires a pen and any notebook. Very customizable for your own needs.

posts.title: Test Checklist by Dr. Richard Felder
posts.intro: Do you think you deserve a better grade on the test? I would argue that if you do not fill the checklist, you have no reason to get a better grade; you would fool nobody but yourself.
posts.content:
The question 'How should I prepare for the test' becomes easy once you've filled out the checklist.
The answer is...
Do whatever it takes to be able to answer 'Yes' to most of the questions.

posts.title: Study Tactics from Cal Newport
posts.intro: Practice active recall - do not simply look things up. Experiment with different types of study tactics. Clear your svhedule, stop being busy.
posts.content: Cal Newport is a professor at Georgtown. He is the author of the Study Hacks blog and has written several books on study techniques and work, such as 'Deep Work' and 'So good they can't ignore you'.

posts.title: Cognitive Bias Codex
posts.intro: A map of common biases, which is categorized into 'Too Much Information', 'Need To Act Fast', 'Not Enough Meaning' and 'What Should We Remember?'
posts.content: To further deep dive into these biases, have a look at Wikipedia

posts.title: Dunning Kruger Effect
posts.intro: Inflated self-perception, to think oneself greater than the objective truth. Failure to recognize genuine skill in others.

posts.title: The 7 habits of highly effective artists
posts.intro: Andrew Price tries to become a good artist. He figures out habits which are paramount for quick learning and imporvement.
posts.content:
• Be specific of what you want to learn
  • Practice actively - No multitasking/doodling
  • Find sources of inspiration
  • Have a loss averse incentive, i.e. take 'damage' if you fail to complete a goal
  • 60% of the time teaches you the most and covers 90% of the work; the last 40% is just perfection and does not produce a lot.

posts.title: Rapid prototyping with the Pomodoro technique
posts.intro: Set a timer for 30 min, take a 5 min break. This specific article explains how to use this technique for web design.
posts.content: The Pomodoro technique is great when learning new things too!

posts.title: Google Five keys to a successful team
posts.intro: Psychological safety, dependability, structure & clarity, meaning, impact.

posts.title: Create deep trust within a team
posts.intro: Say what you think and allow conflicts as often as necessary.

posts.title: Google Design Sprint Kit
posts.intro: Resource for design sprints. Contains icebreakers, double (tripple) diamond design process and facilitation techniques.
posts.content:
Can be used for

  • Product innovation
  • Team building
  • Design process

posts.title: TIN EYE: Reverse Image Search
posts.intro: Search by image and find where that image appears online.
posts.content: This website is the best for reverse image searching, it easily helps us in finding the source of the image uploaded.
